thread.title: Longmont, state cross fingers for $269M federal disaster recovery grant
thread.title_full: Longmont, state cross fingers for $269M federal disaster recovery grant - The Denver Post

author: Karen Antonacci
title: Longmont, state cross fingers for $269M federal disaster recovery grant
text:
State officials laid out Colorado's plan to win a $269 million flood recovery grant before 30 curious residents as part of a public hearing on the state's application Thursday night.
More than a third of that $269 million request would benefit the Longmont area if the state of Colorado wins the money.
Colorado is competing against 39 other communities around the country in phase two of a federal grant competition funded through the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Rockefeller Foundation.
The competition will parcel out $1 billion total, with a maximum award of $500 million to any one applicant.
To qualify, a community must have had a presidentially declared natural disaster in 2011, 2012, or 2013 and have a plan to reduce the damage of future natural disasters..
The state is applying for money on behalf of Boulder, Larimer and El Paso counties, and Longmont's Resilient St. Vrain project makes up roughly 36 percent of the state's $269 million request, not including an extra $12.8 million in requested administration cost reimbursement.
The $194 million Resilient St. Vrain aims to widen the river channel in several places from Airport Road to Sandstone Ranch, decreasing the floodplain and allowing for economic development in the city's core.
Resilient St. Vrain also includes building an educational center on the river and extending the St. Vrain Greenway from St. Vrain Park to Lyons.
Advertisement The rest of the state's $256.3 million ask of the federal government will cover a Larimer County project called the Northern Colorado Connectivity Project. The NCCP would improve four watersheds, improve bridges along Interstate 25 and invest in affordable housing along I-25 from roughly Westminster to Fort Collins.
In total the state's $269 million request to the federal government is:
• $91.3 million for the Resilient St. Vrain project
• $86.9 million for the Northern Colorado Connectivity Project
• $79.1 million to start the Colorado Resiliency Program, which will make capital investments to sure up communities against natural disasters
• $12.8 million for administrative costs
The $269 million ask is being leveraged against $163.5 million in matching funds from different communities:
• $102.7 million from Longmont and Boulder County for Resilient St. Vrain
• $54 million for the NCCP
• $6.9 million for the Colorado Resiliency Program
Altogether, the state's plan would cost $432.6 million.
Longmont City Manager Harold Dominguez said at Thursday's public hearing that the sheer amount of money available as part of the federal grant could fill a huge funding gap in the Resilient St. Vrain project.
"It would have a significant impact to our community and enable us to do the work we need to do and have funding available to cover that gap," Dominguez said. "The funding would allow us to protect a huge number of people from floods."
Gaythia Weis, a Longmont resident, who talked to city and state staff about Resilient St. Vrain and Colorado's grant application said she was excited about the plans.
"There are really some good visionary ideas," Weis said.
The state has until October 27 to submit their phase 2 application and the grant winners will be announced in January. The state's application is available and residents can submit comments at ColoradoUnited.com
